We sold businesses and there are still some empty premises in southern cities that we have not yet either re-let or sold. So yes, there will be further cost improvement, but fundamentally I would expect a revenue increase and to get what I would call a decent return on equity by something like 2015.

So again, we will present figures for Russia. My conviction when I look at the business models in Europe, I'm not particularly confident in the growth in Europe in the next two to three years. I'm not that confident on the evolution of retail. We have here I think a way to improve significantly the businesses, develop synergies, and effectively deliver profitability acceptable even with capital allocated in all the environments in this country. So we will present that more in detail when momentum is positive. For me, 2013 is a year of confirmation for that.

I have a follow-up to your questions on Russia. The question is you want to develop the revenues and obviously to develop the corporate franchise and develop the loan activities. However, looking at Q4 and Q3, loans are down; and if we look at the loan-to-deposit ratio, it's still at a high 125%. Isn't it a huge constraint to develop the loan activity? In fact, it is the question to develop the deposit base, or really to develop the loan activity itself? Thank you.

It's really both. It's not just loans. When I talk about the development in Investment Banking business, and obviously I also control actions I cannot comment. It's also to help companies not only to issue bonds locally but also on the international markets.

But regarding effectively the business, it's effectively to further develop our deposit base knowing that we started with, again, Rosbank, which have deposits but also this consumer finance business which is everything else, which has no deposits. So here again, like for our other subsidiaries, there is effectively a progressive need to rebalance and effectively collect more retail deposits, again, in a very immature market on the retail side altogether, more retail deposits going forward and maintain a good balance between loans and deposits.

Yes, hello, Alex Koagne from Natixis, just one very quick question on the funded balance sheet. I saw that the excess liquidity – the excess long-term liquidity is down Q-on-Q. I was just wondering whether this is a sign that you are very comfortable with the structure of your balance sheet right now and that you should not keep on increasing the excess liquidity, or is it just an optical, let's say picture? And I was just wondering if you are very comfortable with your short-term funding representing 20% of your balance sheet, thank you.
Bertrand?

The question is whether we are comfortable with today's situation or not. I think we'll continue, as Frédéric says, to slowly change the situation. I think where we are today compared to where we were last year, there is a great achievement. Now we will – I don't think you really see some massive changes going forward. This being said, deposits are likely to increase. That's what they say in France and outside France, which I've discussed Russia. And this is a fundamental element of restructuring the balance sheet because more deposits you have, the less outside funding you need.

And within this outside funding, you can split between long term which is kind of a given. We think that we can raise €20 billion at six to seven years of average duration, and then you can basically find out what kind of short-term financing you need. And whatever is in excess can go straight to the Central Bank is exactly what is happening to it. So that's really basically the math of our balance sheet today. So the main elements going forward would be really to have a rebalancing of this loan-to-deposit ratio, which will happen to a certain extent naturally and to a certain extent with some push on our side.

And after that, there is a 20% short-term I think it's, again, a roughly that we have in mind knowing that we use that for market activities and, of course, also to have some money in the Central Bank. So I would not expect a dramatic change today.

Again, it's not short-term money used for long-term financing. Clearly, this is one of the lessons learned from the crisis of 2011. We have been able at that time to adjust our market activities rapidly. And now we are driving our market activities with that in mind. So whenever there is a problem, we can really adjust the volumes of our market activities very rapidly.
So the 20% of today is not exactly the 20% of 18 months ago. That's what we think.
And, Frédéric, just a really quick question about the so-called competitiveness tax credit. Do you expect any impact on your non-French business anywhere?

Again, this competitiveness credit is tax relief. Let me say a slight positive, but overall we will pay more taxes in 2013 than in 2012 with the other increases. And I will not go further on this thing. But I think all together between 2009 and 2013, the group will pay an additional €300 million of additional taxes of all sorts, social, corporate, systemic, whatever. So, yes, some benefit but it will not change the picture.
Which will mostly impact, of course, our French retail network and the structure of this tax relief.
Okay, any other questions?
The last question in Paris.
No more questions in Paris.

Just a quick follow-up, Jeremy Sigee at Barclays. I apologize if I missed this at the start. Could you give the Basel 3 RWAs? You changed the roadmap a little bit. So have you given or could you give where you think Basel 3 RWAs were at the end of 2012 and where you see them at the end of 2013?

I think we provided some figures last year, which to be honest, I don't have on the top of my head today which are more or less still valid on average, so you should rely on that. Adjustments, as I said before you arrived, were mostly related to some volatility elements which are mostly related to the structure of Basel 3 and namely the tax deferred assets which is not directly an RWA question. And also the VaR on CVA, which is still a work in progress in terms of calculation.
Okay, thanks.
Okay. You have questions. Sorry, sorry, yes.

A very quick question. So if you're thinking about a stable balance sheet, you'll get to a core Tier 1 around 9.5% by at the end of the year potentially. You still have a low dividend payout of 25%. So what could that mean for your capital ratios going forward and your dividend payout?

That's a very good question and this is something we will effectively have to address by year end. And again, I want to work a little bit more on that. I have in mind, of course, to potentially increase the payout ratio, but there would be this question of balance between the payout ratio and further invest in the businesses. What I want to check – and again that's why I need more visibility on the rules still. Of course, the profitability of the business is once everything is more or less decided, and I think it's better to wait still and to optimize the balance going forward in 2014. We will stick I think to we will see where we will end 2013. But I stick at the end of the day for the time being at 25% for 2013. We will see for 2014 – 2015 having a better view on again all the potential of the businesses. I have in mind a potential increase of the payout ratio.
We have one last question on the line.
We have a question from John, please. Sir, please go ahead.

Thank you, just one very brief clarification. As you were running through slide 11 with the group cost of risk, I believe you indicated that you thought that the group level in 2013 will be quite similar to the group level in 2012; i.e., around 75 basis points, so the increase in the French Networks is compensated elsewhere. Was that the correct understanding? Thanks.

Yes, in practice as we said we would expect this increase from 50 to 60 basis points in the French retail, potentially a slight decrease in the international retail, as we said, basically and related to Romania; the rest, to be frank, more or less stable, we do not see any reason for big changes in Specialized Financing, and I must say on the corporate side, the large corporates has overall a sound situation, plenty of liquidity. So, yes, in practice that's what we have in mind.
Great, thank you.
We have no other questions on the line.

Just one follow-on question please. I think you might have mentioned this before. But could you confirm what the profitability of the Egyptian NSGB business was in 2012, and could we take that as a proxy for what the decrease in the profitability of the international business will be go forward 2Q and onwards?

And then just following on from an earlier question on slide 40, you do have a notable decrease in the CIB. I was wondering if you could just give a bit more color on that going forward and what has actually happened there.

Thank Yes, perhaps on Egypt, we will have first €100 million roughly in 2012, but let's say around €100 million contribution roughly in 2012. We have the Q1 quarter in 2013, and the balance between the disappearance of Geniki and the disappearance of Egypt should be slightly positive overall because you have to take out the losses of Geniki in 2012 and the contribution of Egypt, and I have in mind that it will always look positive.

CIB, we have a decrease of credit. It's the benefit of the deleverage. And keep in mind, before you get Geniki out of the balance sheet, your need to close the deals in practice, so you can have provisioning of the deleveraging quarter before, what else, some interest – some currency elements also. The dollar increased. And the legacy assets, yes, because, as we said, this shift between risk-weighted assets and the legacy assets and more deduction. So here from a capital point of view it's neutral but it's a treatment, it's a Basel III treatment, less risk-weighted assets, more deduction direct from the capital. These are the three elements.

And it's also I think . Part of this is loans to financial institutions which, at year end, might have some seasonal impact last year. So it doesn't change anything regarding the [delevering] trend going back to one of the questions I think from Kinner on the corporate book. It's mostly related to year-end impact of relationship with financial institutions.
Are we done for today? Okay, thank you very much for your attention. Thank you, good evening.
Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the conference call. Thank you all for attending. You may now disconnect.
